Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Conceptualizing the Adaptive Significance of Brown Adipose Tissue in Cold Climates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Arctic regions present extreme environmental stresses, such as severe cold and low biodiversity; yet, human populations have managed to survive in these territories for thousands of years. As human populations migrated into high-latitude regions, they underwent an adaptive shift that included cultural, behavioral and biological dimensions. Contemporary circumpolar populations appear to adapt to cold temperatures physiologically by generating high metabolic rates; however, the mechanisms that control this biological adaptation are poorly understood. Brown adipose tissue (BAT), a special type of fat that is highly metabolically active, has been recognized for decades as the primary source of heat production among infants. However, it was previously assumed that as humans develop, BAT levels decrease to trace amounts. Within recent years, BAT has been discovered to be present and active among many adults. Furthermore, due its ability to convert stored fats and sugars into heat, the presence of BAT may have protective effects against obesity. It is not known why some adults have BAT while others do not, and whether BAT activity is adaptive against cold temperatures. This project will examine variation in BAT activity among indigenous and non-indigenous populations living in cold climates to enhance our understanding of biological adaptations to cold; early-life factors that may shape adult metabolism; and population variation in metabolic disease risk. In addition, the project will support training of a female graduate student in the STEM sciences, foster research collaborations, and provide a new, portable method for quantifying fat metabolic activity.

An elevated resting metabolic rate (RMR) and efficient non-shivering thermogenesis (NST) are central biological adaptations to cold climates, but the mechanisms that dictate these metabolic adaptations are poorly understood. Researchers have recently discovered that brown adipose tissue (BAT), a form of fat that is highly thermogenic, is present among adults. This study investigates multiple levels of adaptation to cold stress by testing hypotheses regarding variation in adult BAT heat production. The proposed one-year study will compare groups living in Siberia that have been exposed to cold stress over various time depths. BAT activity will be quantified using infrared thermal imaging of the neck and shoulders. RMR will be measured using indirect calorimetry. Participants will wear temperature loggers for 72 hours to quantify average daily cold exposure. Anthropometric measurements will be taken using standardized techniques. Finally, a modified survey will be used to collect data on lifestyle, socioeconomic status and early-life cold exposure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Arctic regions present extreme environmental stresses, such as severe cold; yet, human populations have managed to survive in these territories for thousands of years. As humans migrated into high-latitude regions, they underwent an adaptive shift that included cultural, behavioral and biological dimensions. Contemporary circumpolar populations appear to adapt to cold temperatures by generating high metabolic rates; however, the mechanisms that control this biological adaptation are poorly understood. Brown adipose tissue (BAT), a special type of fat that is highly metabolically active, has been recognized for decades as the primary source of heat production among infants.  However, it was previously assumed that as humans develop, BAT levels decrease to trace amounts. Within recent years, BAT has been discovered to be present and active among many adults. When adults with BAT deposits are exposed to cold stress, their BAT becomes activated and converts energy stored in fats and sugars into heat through a process called BAT thermogenesis. Because of this, the presence of BAT may have protective effects against obesity. Explanations for why some adults have BAT while others do not, and whether BAT activity is adaptive against cold temperatures are currently unknown.

The goal of this project was to compare variation in BAT activity among an indigenous population of northeastern Siberia, called the Yakut, and adults in Evanston, IL and examine the relationship between BAT metabolism and whole-body energy expenditure as well as biomarkers of cardio-metabolic health. Identifying the determinants of BAT activity will shed light on population variation in cardio-metabolic disease risk. Additionally, this research enhances our understanding of the possible biological adaptations that facilitated human migration into high latitudes.

 

Yakut BAT Thermogenesis and Energy Expenditure 

We found evidence suggesting that BAT plays a role in metabolic adaptation to cold stress among Yakut adults. Yakut adults that exhibited greater BAT thermogenesis, as measured by change in skin temperature of the supraclavicular area after 30 minutes of cooling, also experienced a larger increase in energy expenditure. These results suggest that Yakut adults with greater BAT stores are able to produce a larger increase in metabolism in response to cold stress and, thus, produce more heat.

 

Yakut BAT Thermogenesis and Cardio-metabolic Health

Among Yakut young adults, BAT thermogenesis was positively associated with percent body fat. It is possible that among relatively young and healthy adults, greater fat stores may signal that there is more energy available for BAT metabolism. BAT thermogenesis was not associated with blood lipid levels. However, the results did present a significant positive association between BAT thermogenesis, and respiratory quotient and fasted blood glucose levels. These results suggest that greater BAT thermogenesis may lead to preferential utilization of carbohydrates as a fuel source.

 

Developmental Plasticity in BAT Thermogenesis among the Yakut

This work documents the first evidence of developmental plasticity in BAT in response to low temperatures during developmental stages. Yakut adults that spent more time outside during the winter between ages three and five years old exhibit greater BAT thermogenesis in adulthood. It is possible that as kids become more mobile and independent, they may be exposed to greater cold stress. Cultural norms like infant bundling may push back the timing of sensitivity by buffering infants from exposure to low temperatures. Additionally, participants that experienced colder years at ages three to five and ages 15 to 16 years old exhibit more BAT thermogenesis as adults. Previous work has found that BAT volume increases around the time of puberty. It is possible that hormonal changes around puberty are sensitive to environmental conditions and may influence BAT growth. Thus, these results suggest that early childhood and puberty may act as critical periods for shaping adult BAT thermogenesis.

 

Comparative Analyses of BAT in Yakutia and Evanston

Our preliminary analyses suggest that, in response to mild cooling, Yakut adults may rely on BAT for thermogenesis to a greater degree than a sample of adults in Evanston, IL. Additionally, the relationship between BAT thermogenesis and percent change in energy expenditure after cooling was stronger among adults in Yakutia than in Evanston. Adults in Evanston, however, were more likely to shiver in response to mild cooling.

 

Broader Impacts

The project promoted teaching by engaging undergraduate and graduate students at Northwestern University and North-Eastern Federal University (NEFU) in biological anthropology concepts and methods. Previous work investigating human BAT function has used PET-CT scans, which are expensive, immobile and invasive. By advancing a new methodology for quantifying BAT activity, this project broadens the participation of underrepresented groups, particularly rural populations and indigenous minorities. The results of this research will hopefully inform approaches to improving cardio-metabolic health.
